author: Donna-Lee Biddle
title: Kuggeleijn rape trial: Complainant's clothes 'provocative'
text:
Kuggeleijn rape trial: Complainant's clothes 'provocative' DONNA-LEE BIDDLE Last updated 17:08, February 22 2017 DOMINICO ZAPATA/FAIRFAX NZ. 
Northern Districts cricketer Scott Kuggeleijn arrived at the Hamilton District Court on Monday. 

She wore a skirt above her knees and a singlet top - her clothes were 'provocative', according to a cricketer on trial for rape. 
Northern Districts all-rounder Scott Christopher Kuggeleijn, 25, is defending one charge of raping a woman in her bed in May 2015. 
The jury heard from the cricketer on the third day of a week-long trial at the Hamilton District Court on Wednesday. 
"She was wearing a skirt above her knees and a singlet top. You thought her dressing in this way was provocative?" Crown prosecutor Jacinda Foster said to Kuggeleijn. 
"Yes, and the way she acted," Kuggeleijn said. 
Foster asked what the defendant meant by his answer, to which Kuggeleijn replied, "She was exposing a bit more parts of her body than other girls do... I thought she must be quite confident." 
Foster suggested Kuggeleijn formed the view that the complainant was a "very sexual woman". 
"Did you decide that she was looking for someone to hook up," Foster said. 
"I though it was a possibility I guess, I wasn't thinking too much about that," Kuggeleijn told the court. Ad Feedback 
On the night before the alleged incident in May 2015, Kuggeleijn and the complainant were drinking at an 18th birthday party with a group of mutual friends. 
During some stage in the night, the defendant allegedly told a friend that he thought the complainant "loved penis". 
Foster quizzed him on this. 
"A woman that loved penis; [is this] expressing the view that she was a woman who loved sex?" Foster said. 
"Yeah, well sex or whatever, whatever she wanted... Those are words said after a fair bit of alcohol at a party. Not necessarily just sex but that comes into it I suppose," Kuggeleijn said. 
"She looked like she liked a lot of male attention, she liked males." 
Kuggeleijn denied forcing himself onto the complainant and said she was lying when Foster referred to evidence read to the court by the complainant on Monday. 
"I suggest that when she tried to resist you, you were more forceful about it... doing the things she knew would arouse you, but not letting you have sex." 
"I did not force myself on her like she said," Kuggeleijn said, "She is lying, yes." 
Defence counsel Philip Morgan, QC, asked Kuggeleijn whether he and the complainant were "completely engaged" during their time together. 
To which Kuggeleijn said, yes. 
"She seemed liked she was into it... she wanted it to happen." 
The trial opened before Judge David Wilson, QC, at the Hamilton District Court on Monday. 
Earlier in the week, the court heard from the complainant and five other witnesses for the Crown. 
The complainant described being so intoxicated that she could not remember parts of her night, specifically being in town with Kuggeleijn. 
The alleged rape happened when they returned to her flat in the early hours of the next morning after hours of drinking. 
Morgan, QC, and Foster will give their closing statements on Thursday. - Stuff
